title: 107_hr504
content: The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. The purpose of the Act is outlined in Section 2. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" aims to assist communities and health care consortia, including those in rural areas and American Indian/Alaska Native entities, in developing or strengthening integrated health care delivery systems. This includes coordinating services for uninsured and underinsured individuals to receive efficient, high-quality care and gain access to a comprehensive system of care through effective collaboration and infrastructure development. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" aims to develop a comprehensive system of care through effective collaboration, infrastructure development, and provision of new Federal resources without supplanting funding for existing programs supporting low-income populations. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" establishes a new subpart V - Community Access Program under Part D of title III of the Public Health Service Act. This subpart includes grants to enhance services for the uninsured and underinsured. The Secretary may grant funds to develop integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured communities, expanding services and improving efficiency among providers. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit organizations like Federally qualified health centers. The Secretary may grant funds to public or nonprofit entities like Federally qualified health centers, hospitals meeting specific requirements, or public health departments. Entities eligible for grants include those that represent a consortium of providers with the principal purpose of offering coordinated healthcare services for specific communities or special population groups. Entities eligible for grants must represent a consortium of healthcare providers serving specific communities or special populations, including migrant and seasonal farm workers, homeless individuals, and those with disabilities. The consortium should include all healthcare providers that traditionally offer care to uninsured and underinsured individuals regardless of their ability to pay, and may also involve other healthcare providers and related agencies. To be eligible for a grant, an entity must define a community of uninsured and underinsured individuals in a specific geographical area. Preference is given to healthcare providers identified in the previous paragraph. Applications must be submitted to the Secretary in the prescribed form and manner. The entity must define a community of uninsured and underinsured individuals in a specific geographical area, identify participating providers, and describe their contributions to care. The consortium applying for the grant must describe their proposed activities to further the purposes of the grant, demonstrate their ability to involve providers who traditionally serve uninsured and underinsured individuals, and show their capability to develop coordinated systems of high-quality care. The consortium applying for the grant must demonstrate their ability to develop coordinated systems of care that provide a broad range of high-quality services, involve the community in program development, and ensure enrollment in public programs. The consortium applying for the grant must demonstrate the ability to ensure participants are enrolled in public insurance programs, leverage various funding sources for sustainability, and have a plan for evaluating program activities. The grant applicant must describe a plan for evaluating program activities, demonstrate fiscal responsibility, include information as prescribed by the Secretary, and show a commitment to providing free or reduced charge care for the poor. The Secretary may prioritize grant applicants with a consortium including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and other providers that are covered entities. The program must identify a community with a high percentage of uninsured individuals, include health care providers serving uninsured and underinsured individuals, and show evidence of expanding preventive and primary care services, including mental health and substance abuse services. The proposed program aims to improve coordination between health care providers and social service providers, collaborate with State and local governments, utilize non-Federal contributions, and show a likelihood of success. The grant program encourages collaboration with State and local governments, utilization of non-Federal contributions, and sustainability of the proposed program after support ends. Grantees can use funds for expenses related to integrating a health care delivery system. The grant program supports the integration of a health care delivery system to provide a broad range of services, including primary, secondary, and tertiary care, substance abuse treatment, and mental health services. It also allows for direct patient care and service expansions within the integrated system. The grant program supports the integration of a health care delivery system by providing funds for various purposes such as increasing outreach activities, improving case management, coordinating transportation to health care facilities, and developing provider networks. The grant program supports the integration of a health care delivery system by providing funds for various purposes such as developing provider networks, recruiting necessary personnel, acquiring technology, and improving provider communication. The grant program supports the integration of health care delivery systems by funding activities like developing provider networks, recruiting personnel, acquiring technology, and improving communication. Funds provided under the grant have limitations on direct patient care to 15%, with a reservation of 3% for national program purposes. The Secretary may allocate up to 3% of funds for technical assistance, expert consultation, meetings, dissemination of information, and extending program benefits to other communities. Grants require recipients to maintain non-Federal fund expenditures for authorized activities. The recipient of a grant must agree to maintain non-Federal fund expenditures at or above the previous year's level. They must also report annually to the Secretary on their progress and provide any additional information requested. The Secretary cannot renew a grant without this information. The Secretary may not renew an annual grant under this section unless satisfied with the consortium's progress in meeting grant goals. Each grant recipient must undergo an independent annual financial audit. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to funded entities. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to funded entities through grants or contracts. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006.
